docs.lead_paragraph: One after another, the girls, looking even younger than they are despite the painted lips and cheeks, tell similar stories of being lured or coerced from their homes in Burmese hill towns to the cubicles of Thailand, where they were rented out as virgins two or three or more times before settling into the practiced prostitute's life. One tells of her father's urging, ''Go to Thailand and see the world.'' What he meant was for her to see the inside of a bar or a brothel and send some money home. In her village, a girl might earn a bowl of noodles for a day's work. In Bangkok, she might be dressed in colorful fabrics -- ''I was so proud in these new clothes'' -- and perhaps be able to save a few dollars to help support her parents.

headline.main: Girls Are the Victims In Thai Sex Industry

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews POV television documentary Sacrifice, about young girls lured into prostitution in Thailand's sex industry; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: HAVING grandchildren is supposed to be a storybook experience: snapshots of laughter and hugs, the license to indulge the little ones with gifts and extra helpings of dessert before returning them to Mom and Dad. But for growing numbers of grandparents, joyful dates with the grandchildren have been replaced by the responsibility of full-time child care. And doctors and other health care professionals are just now beginning to see that the demands are taking a toll on many grandparents' health. It is not just that grandparents are exhausted from chasing after 2-year-olds and juggling after-school activities. They are suffering from problems like depression, anxiety, high blood pressure, alcoholism and strokes that doctors link in part to the stress of being parents all over again, this time under far more difficult circumstances than the first time around.

headline.main: Rising Stress of Raising a Grandchild

docs.abstract: Stress suffered by many grandparents who are raising grandchildren discussed; social worker Susan Silverstein and Dr Ronald Adelman comment on stress-related illness, depression and other ailments, and need for support services; photos (S)
docs.snippet: HAVING grandchildren is supposed to be a storybook experience: snapshots of laughter and hugs, the license to indulge the little ones with gifts and extra helpings of dessert before returning them to Mom and Dad. But for growing numbers of...

docs.lead_paragraph: While much of the rest of the world was savoring one of John Williams's latest film scores on Saturday evening, in Steven Spielberg's new drama, ''Saving Private Ryan,'' Mr. Williams and 8,000 or so listeners were attending to another, much more delicate of his new creations here at the Tanglewood Festival. Mr. Williams conducted the Boston Symphony Orchestra in the premiere of a lovely orchestral song cycle, ''Seven for Luck,'' with Cynthia Haymon as the soprano soloist. This sketchy but insightful account of a black woman's life consists of seven settings of enchanting poems by Rita Dove, three of which Ms. Haymon and Mr. Williams had previewed in May with the Boston Pops. Ms. Dove, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 and was Poet Laureate of the United States from 1993 to 1995, was on hand here to read two of her poems.

headline.main: Circling Back To a Time Of Mystery And Wonder

docs.abstract: James R Oestreich reviews John Williams conducting Boston Symphony Orchestra in premier of his orchestral song cycle, Seven for Luck, with Cynthia Haymon as soprano soloist, at Tanglewood Festival (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NO one else runs an opera company, or talks about opera, with the fervor of Speight Jenkins. ''You see, in 'Tristan und Isolde,' Wagner wanted everyone in the audience to experience his frustration in not being able to consummate his love for Mathilde Wesendonck,'' Mr. Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, said recently, warming to his favorite topic. ''He couldn't have her, and so we have to feel it. It's the apotheosis of erotic yearning, the absolute pinnacle of all his works, of all opera.'' The Seattle Opera's new production of ''Tristan und Isolde,'' which opens on Saturday evening, brings together the hottest Wagner singers of the moment, the Canadian tenor Ben Heppner and the English soprano Jane Eaglen, for the first time in the title roles. As the opera world waits to see whether Ms. Eaglen and Mr. Heppner are the Flagstad and Melchior for the new millennium, outsiders might assume that it was Seattle's high-tech money that attracted such big names.
docs.abstract: Seattle Opera general director Speight Jenkins comments on new production of Tristan und Isolde featuring tenor Ben Heppner and soprano Jane Eaglen; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Countering decades of promoting ''breast is best'' for infant nutrition, the United Nations is issuing recommendations intended to discourage women infected with the AIDS virus from breast-feeding. The much-debated step aims at preventing transmission of H.I.V., the AIDS virus, from mothers to babies in what United Nations officials say is ''a runaway epidemic'' in many developing countries. United Nations officials said they were reluctant to issue a blanket warning because the decision should be left to each mother and because no simple message could encompass the diversity of environments where women live. Women may become stigmatized for not breast-feeding in some cultures, and in some places alternatives like formula can be unaffordable or unsafe, but the United Nations wants that to change.

headline.main: AIDS BRINGS A SHIFT ON BREAST-FEEDING

docs.abstract: United Nations, which has long promoted breast-feeding of infants, is issuing recommendations aimed at discouraging nursing by women infected with AIDS virus; cites concern about soaring HIV infection rates in much of world and mother-to-child transmission of virus; fears move may spur women who are not infected to stop nursing, needlessly exposing babies to risks posed by formula mixed under unsanitary conditions; advises governments to weigh bulk purchases of formula and other milk substitutes and to dispense them mainly through prescriptions; fact that some 90 percent of infected people in developing nations do not know they are infected complicates policy; graph of number of children newly infected with HIV through mother-to-child contact (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the past few years the Federal Government and private researchers have issued a number of reports depicting dramatic improvement in the quality of life for America's black population. High school completion rates have reached parity with those of whites. Birth rates among single black women have hit a 40-year low. Homicide rates have declined to the levels of the 1960's. Poverty rates have dipped below 30 percent of black households for the first time in the country's history. The home ownership rate is up. The jobless rate is down. Somebody tell Julian Bond.

headline.main: The Nation; Good Times Are Bad For Interest Groups

docs.abstract: Advocacy groups from across political spectrum have issued dark assessments and dire warnings about current racial, moral, financial and social climate, even as country enjoys peace and prosperity and is arguably less racist, less sexist, less dangerous and less polluted than it has been in decades--and perhaps, ever; distance between dispassionate analysis and advocates' oratory raises question of how groups that see mission as correcting injustice handle good times; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Patsy Southgate, a writer and translator who helped inspire the literary flowering of Paris in the 1950's and later helped establish the writers' colony on eastern Long Island, becoming a beloved intimate of many of the leading artists of her day, died on July 18 at the Stony Brook University Hospital and Medical Center. A resident of Springs, N.Y., she was 70, and for a decade had been reviewing plays and writing profiles for The East Hampton Star. Her family said the cause was a stroke. If her own poems, short stories, plays, and an unpublished novel did not put her in a league with the coterie of young writers who gravitated to her orbit in Paris, it was partly because they included such literary luminaries as William Styron, James Baldwin, Richard Wright, Terry Southern, a middle-aged Irwin Shaw and her own husband, Peter Matthiessen.

headline.main: Patsy Southgate, Who Inspired 50's Literary Paris, Dies at 70

docs.lead_paragraph: THE coupons arrived by the handful when Janlori Goldman was pregnant with her daughter, and she couldn't figure out how the companies knew she was expecting. There were coupons for parenting magazines, baby announcements, diapers and children's book clubs. ''I started to wonder,'' she said. ''Where are they getting this information? Is the hospital selling it? Is my doctor making it available?'' She never got an answer, but to Ms. Goldman, the questions were of more than passing interest. As the founder of the Health Privacy Project at Georgetown University, her goal is to raise the public's awareness about the erosion of medical privacy. It has been an uphill battle. ''Privacy,'' Ms. Goldman said, ''has not always been a top-line issue.''

headline.main: The Nation: The Numbering of America; Medical I.D.'s and Privacy (Or What's Left of It)

docs.abstract: Article examines consideration by Clinton Administration--following 1996 Congressional mandate--to assign every American health-care identification number that could be used to create giant electronic data base capable of tracking everyone's medical records from cradle to grave; just how information would be used and who would have access to it remains unclear; even though 35 states have enacted laws intended to protect privacy of patients, there are no Federal protections (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Was it fair that Amy Grossberg was sentenced to two and a half years in prison and Brian Peterson to two years in the death of their newborn? Not Enough Time The sentence was absolutely unjust. Amy knew she was pregnant for months and could have obtained help but, in her own selfish way, planned to do away with this baby. Brian Peterson was no better in abiding by her wishes and in throwing away this newborn like garbage. They could have left the baby in front of a church, hospital or even in the motel. They should have been given the maximum of 8 to 10 years or at least 5 years. GRACE JACOBS Cliffside Park More Than 'Mistakes' Everyone makes mistakes, it's true, but I find it appalling to put the creation and dismissal of a life in the same category as running a red light or taking a wrong turn on a road or forgetting your homework. That's how I hear unwanted pregnancies described, and that's how I hear the Grossberg-Peterson murder described: just kids who made a mistake. I'd like to think creation is more sacred and deserves our utmost respect. CHRISTINE VARTANIAN Queens, N.Y. Education Not Sticking The thing I found most disturbing was Amy's notes to Brian saying she couldn't wait until this was over so they could have sex again because she felt ugly being pregnant. They saw the pregnancy as an annoyance. It's amazing that in the late 90's, sex ed class doesn't stick in these kids' heads, and the parents are too immature or ignorant to explain sex (and its risks and consequences) to their kids. K.C. JACKSON Teaneck He Behaved Worse In terms of whose behavior was worse the night of the birth, I vote for Brian Peterson. Amy was involved in drug-free childbirth -- not usually a pleasant experience -- and Brian was there apparently to assist. He should have been the more clear-headed of the two and had the option to take the baby and run for the nearest phone to dial 911 instead of running for the nearest Dumpster to throw it in. PAM ROLAND West Orange Robbers Would Get More How is it possible that someone who robs can get a longer sentence than someone who is responsible for the death of another human being? KATHERINE PACHECO Elizabeth
docs.abstract: Reader response to query about sentencing of Amy Grossberg and Brian Peterson in death of their newborn (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A July 16 front-page article on a House panel's vote to approve $3.5 billion for the International Monetary Fund mischaracterizes the family-planning issue. Rhetoric equating support for family planning with support for abortion is political -- even if many family-planning advocates support both. Being pro-family planning is strongly anti-abortion, whatever one's position on access to safe abortion.

headline.main: Politics Overwhelmed Policy in House I.M.F. Vote
